    Resumption of Debate on Question (19th March. 1976).

    "That the sum to be allocated for Head R be reduced by $10 in respect of subhead BEA 1 107."-(Mr Teong Eng Siong).

    Question again proposed.

    The Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Social Affairs (Mr Chan Chee Seng): Mr Speaker, Sir, there are a number of voluntary organisations that serve handicapped children. Some of them maintain homes for such children while others run schools and training centres. Disabled children should, wherever possible, remain in their own homes where their families can give them the personal care, attention and love that are very necessary for their growth and development. Children may be admitted into residential institutions only as a last resort. With this view, every possible assistance is given to encourage families to care for their disabled children in their own homes. This includes training and education provided by voluntary welfare organisations and counselling and welfare for the children and their families. In this respect, the Government helps voluntary welfare organisations to provide those essential services by disbursing quarterly grants to meet administrative expenses and salaries of the numerous teaching staff employed in the voluntary welfare organisations.

    The voluntary organisations have very ably provided welfare services for the disabled, and the Government will continue to provide support through consultation and financial assistance. The Government does not, however, intend to duplicate the work of

Column: 718

these organisations but will work more closely with them to achieve a more effective service for the public. In this connection, voluntary welfare organisations do from time to time submit proposals to expand their facilities. Our Ministry has always supported such proposals and will continue to support any organisation prepared to construct homes for handicapped children who need admission into residential institutions.

    Mr Teong Eng Siong (Sembawang)(In Mandarin): Sir, before I withdraw my amendment, I would like to ask the Senior Parliamentary Secretary two questions. In his answer, he said that his Ministry has always encouraged private charitable and welfare organisations to expand their work and will support any organisation that is prepared to build homes for disabled children. This is, of course, very good and I hope that his Ministry can implement this policy effectively. According to my information there are about 8,000 disabled children and they are in a very pitiful state. In view of the present inadequate capacity of the homes to accommodate all of them, I hope the Social Welfare Department can do something concrete to help such an unfortunate lot.

    I would like to ask him another question. Recently the Social Welfare Department has been promoting a "Return to the society" campaign for the aged people living in institutional homes. This campaign is to encourage them to go back to their personal home environment so that they can enjoy their remaining years in a more congenial atmosphere with their families. Of course. I agree to this beneficial measure. We must befriend all people and treat the children of other people as our own and respect the elders and the aged of other people as our own. Since we are a democratic socialist state which aims at and pays respect to virtues of a welfare state, I support this policy. However, I would like to ask him for more details and whether he is satisfied with its implementation and achievement so far.

    Mr Ho See Beng (Bras Basah)(In Mandarin): Sir, in Singapore there are quite a number of subnormal children. I would like to ask the Parliamentary Secretary whether

Column: 719

there is any home to accommodate these retarded children and whether the Social Welfare Department has any plan to help them.

    Mr Chan Chee Song(In Mandarin): Mr Speaker, Sir, the Member for Sembawang has raised two questions. On the first question. I would say that we have great confidence in our private charitable and welfare organisations which do welfare work. I have full confidence in their ability to deal with matters of accommodation and rendering service to disabled children.

    The second point about respecting the elders of others as our elders and treating the children of others as our own children, I would say that personally I agree with him but we should not expect the Government to do everything. This is a national problem and we are dealing with the matter on a national basis. What concerns us is to provide practical measures to tackle this problem, such as rendering assistance to private charitable and welfare organisations in their work. If they are able to provide homes we will support them, and we also try to help the old folks to return to their family environment under the "Return to the society" scheme so that they can enjoy a more congenial environment. We are doing this on an experimental basis.

    The old folks staying in these institutional homes still feel lonely in spite of the help and services that we are providing them. There have been quarrels among the old folks too. If we can send them back to their own families, we will do so. For a start, as a Government department we encourage them to have contacts with other sections of our people or to help in simple chores in the institutional homes as well as to establish contact with society and ultimately returning to society. In this way they will not feel lonely and they can prove themselves to be useful. If the various institutions and members of the public can provide them with meaningful activities and social contact, this will help to alleviate their problem and it will go a long way to make our "Return to the society" scheme a success.

Column: 720

On the question of homes for retarded children, we are not establishing any as yet, as the private sector is doing quite well in catering this category of children. As regards what Government has achieved in all these measures or schemes. I would say that we are still awaiting further developments.

    Mr Ho See Bong(In Mandarin): Sir, just now the Senior Parliamentary Secretary said that charitable organisations cannot depend on the Government assistance alone and that members of the public will have t~ do their part. As regards the home for retarded children, I feel that the Government should take the lead by setting out some concrete plans, and not just stress an important need for it.

    Mr Hwang Soo Jin (Jalan Kayu)(In Mandarin): Sir, I fully agree to the points raised by my colleagues on the care of disabled and retarded children.

    I feel that both the Government and members of the public have not done enough towards rendering welfare service in this respect. The Member for Bras Basah has rightly said that the Government should take the lead and should not be content with just stressing its viewpoint only.

    There are only about 300 or 400 places available for disabled children in these homes whereas, there are thousands of disabled children who cannot be well looked after by their families. Members of the family usually have to go out to work and there will be nobody left at home to look after these children. So we cannot just stress that the private sector or members of the public should do more. On the other hand, I would suggest that the Government should take the lead and do something more positive, in terms of physical encouragement besides the moral one.

    Mr Chan Chee Seng(In Mandarin): Sir, we have the Singapore Association for Retarded Children which runs four children's homes. They are the Lee Kuo Chuan Centre, Geylang Centre, Jurong Centre and the Toa Payoh Centre.

    Just now two Members have aired their feelings and I fully sympathise with them. Of

Column: 721

course, looking after such children in their own homes is a problem to their families. But the question is: how are the children affected psychologically? And this is important. It is common to see parents putting their children in the homes and then forget about the whole thing. This will lead to a situation where children once out of sight means out of love. In this way, the children would just dissipate away. My thinking is that the parents should first have to look after their own children. It is only when they cannot tackle this problem, that it becomes the Government's problem to sort things out, as a last resort

    If the Member for Sembawang could raise with us the matter of two cases mentioned earlier, we will consider according to their merits, the possibility of, say, recommending accommodation for the children in an institutional home.

    Mr Teong Eng Siong(In Mandarin): Sir, the Senior Parliamentary Secretary said that he hopes the private sector and members of the public could do something to help the aged to "return to the society". I agree with him on that suggestion. I would like to ask him whether he has got any concrete plan to help the private sector to do what he has suggested.

    Mr Chan Chee Seng(In Mandarin): Sir, I said that this scheme is being experimented at the present. We have not yet come to any concrete solution. If the reaction from the society is good, then we will do something more.

    Mr Teong Eng Siong(In Mandarin): Sir, in view of the detailed explanation given by the Senior Parliamentary Secretary, I beg leave to withdraw my amendment.

    Amendment, by leave, withdrawn.

    Mr Ho Kah Leong (Jurong): Sir, I beg to move,

    That the sum to be allocated for Head R be reduced by $10 in respect of subhead BEC 1111.

    Sir, we all know that creches are established to serve the needs of working mothers. They find it convenient to leave

Column: 722

their children in the creches while they go to work. In an industrialised society the need for creches correspondingly increases with the need for more women to join the workforce. In the present labour-tight situation in Singapore, more women are being encouraged to leave their kitchens and join the workforce. More creches are, therefore, needed, otherwise they cannot be released from their household chores and their children.

2.45 p.m.

    But I was extremely surprised to learn that the creches in Singapore are not well patronised. In other words, they are not as popular as they ought to be. I wonder whether the Ministry of Social Affairs has looked into the reasons why these creches are so poorly patronised. Is it due to poor management, inappropriate location, or is it because the opening hours are unsuitable to them? I would suggest to the Minister to conduct a thorough survey to investigate into this problem further.

    I would also like to suggest to the Minister that a creche need not be an elaborate establishment. The ground floor of an HDB flat or a JTC flat will serve its purpose. In this connection, may I ask the Minister whether his Ministry has any plans to build a creche in Jurong Neighbourhood II, or better known as Boon Lay Garden? There is a creche in Jurong Neighbourhood I, but it is miles away from Boon Lay Garden. Thus its distance away from Boon Lay Garden is inconvenient to the working mothers living in Boon Lay Garden. I met some of my constituents in Boon Lay Garden and they share my view that there should be a creche in Neighbourhood II to encourage mothers to go to work. Can the Minister enlighten this House whether he has any plans to build a creche in Jurong Neighbourhood II?

    Mr Cheong Yuen Chee (Toa Payoh): Mr Speaker, Sir, I would like to support the Member for Jurong in asking whether the present system of running creches is really suitable for the working mothers. The present rate of fees is very discouraging. Firstly, even before an application is approved the working

Column: 723

mother has to pay the full rate of $3 per day. All applicants have to wait until such time as their actual financial standing has been determined before they are allowed the concessionary rate of 20 cents as against $3 per day. This tends to discourage working mothers from putting their children in the creches.

    The other point I would like to raise is the opening hours. The creche in Toa Payoh is open from 7.00 a.m. to 7.00 p.m. I think this does not take into consideration the fact that the factories in the area operate a three-shift system. This is another reason why most of the creches are under-utilised.

    May I suggest that the Ministry review the existing system so that more working mothers would be able to make use of the creches. For those creches which are under-utilised, may I suggest that they should be thrown open to children in primary schools as day centres so that the children will not run around the streets in the housing estates.

    Mr Chan Chee Song: Mr Speaker, Sir, it should be pointed out that the creche services are heavily subsidised. Before a creche is established in any particular area, the Social Welfare Department has to be certain that there is a demand for it. The situation is constantly reviewed and where there is a need more creches will be built. As far as possible creches will be built in the Housing Board estates within industrial areas.

    Although there are plans to establish more Social Welfare Department creches, the present policy is to encourage and help the private sector, especially private industries, and even the smaller factories, to set up their own creches in or near their workplaces to assist working mothers who have young children. The aim is to encourage more women to take up employment in the factories. The Social Welfare Department will advise and assist any firm that wishes to start a creche for its female workers.

    The present Jurong Town creche has a capacity of 100 children. However, only

Column: 724

about 80 to 85 children attend the creche daily. There are still vacant places in the present creche to cater for their needs. A second creche in Jurong will only be considered if the present creche enjoys full attendance and if the demand for a second creche is justified. Future creches to be built by the Government will be small but functional. They will be situated within the blocks of Housing Board flats so as to bring the creche services closer to the families who use them.

    I come now to the Member for Toa Payoh's question about the opening hours and the fees charged by the creches. The creches are open from 7.00 am, to 5.00 p.m. Some of them close a little later if the mothers return to the creches late. We have a system to determine the fees to be charged, as follows:

Family income of $500-$800            ...$1.20 full-day

Family income of $300-$500            ...$0.50 full-day

Recipients of public assistance           ...No Charge.


    Mr Cheong Yuen Chee: Sir, this is precisely the point that I have raised. When a working mother applies for a place for her child, she is charged the maximum rate of $3 pending the verification of the family's income. I would like to repeat that this is a deterrent to the applicants. If a working mother has an income of $300. she is entitled to pay only 20 cents. But in the meantime while an investigation is being conducted, she has to pay $3. Moreover, the opening hours of the creche do not actually help the mothers, the majority of whom are working on a weekly shift, alternating with a day or night shift.

    Mr Ho Kah Leong: Mr Speaker, Sir, the Parliamentary Secretary has mentioned that before a creche can be established, his Ministry will have to find out whether or not there is a demand for it. May I ask how is his Ministry going to ascertain the demand? Can he enlighten this House in this regard?

Column: 725



    I have also pointed out just now that Boon Lay Garden is quite far from the present creche in Jurong Neighbourhood I. In fact, it is about four miles away. We cannot, therefore, expect a working mother to travel a distance of four miles to the creche before going to work. There is indeed an urgent need to build a creche in Boon Lay Garden.

    Mr Chan Chee Song: Sir, the Member for boa Payoh has said that the charge of $3 has deterred working mothers from sending their children to the creches. I do not think so. So far there has been no complaint of the practice whereby when a working mother first sends her child to a creche, she has to pay $3 and only after the family income has been ascertained that the fee will be adjusted accordingly. So far we have not received any complaint of this nature from the mothers.

    Anyway, we have found out that most of the creches are not fully utilised. Even the creche in Jurong has an attendance of only 80 to 85 children. The Member for Jurong has said that another creche is needed in another neighbourhood in his area. I would suggest that he conducts an investigation to establish whether there is really a need for it. We will not construct a creche if there is no patronage, otherwise Government funds will just go down the drain.

    Mr Ho Kah Leong: Sir; although the reply given by the Parliamentary Secretary is not quite satisfactory, I beg leave to withdraw my amendment.

    Amendment, by leave, withdrawn.

    The following amendment stood in the name of Mr Hwang Soo Jin -

    (7) That the sum to be allocated for Head R be reduced by $10 in respect of subhead BED 1111.

    The Chairman: Mr Hwang, amendment (7).

    Mr Hwang Soo Jin: Sir, I do not wish to move amendment (7). May I have your permission to proceed with amendment (8)?

    The Chairman: Yes.

    Mr Hwang Soo Jin: Sir, I beg to move,

    That the sum to be allocated for Head R be reduced by $10 in respect of subhead BEG 1111.

Column: 726



    Sir, to give credit where credit is due, over the years the Social Welfare Department has been found to have provided a reasonable service, notwithstanding the low priority placed on services of a welfare nature. This is reflected by the fact that the expenditure on Social Welfare takes up only 0.24% of the Government's total Estimates of Expenditure for FY 76. The practice in the concept of the so-called welfare state, without considering the wider implications, economic and otherwise, has led to the downfall of many political leaderships in the world and in the process the financial bankruptcy of their countries. I am, therefore, all for careful spending on welfare services. But I have always felt that this is an area of government service where inadequate attention would appear to have been paid to the pooling of human resources and the better coordinated use of existing physical facilities. There would appear generally to be a reluctance between government departments to cooperate even in areas where the services provided by them are of a similar or complementary nature.

    With a very young population as we have today, I can envisage an increasing need and demand for a counselling and advice service. Our young people need to be guided, but in many cases I do not think they know where or who to turn to. Up to this point of time, I believe that the Counselling and Advice Section is involved primarily in helping to settle matrimonial and other family squabbles of a petty nature. I do not think it concerns itself with problems of youths. Except for an office at Pearl's Hill, there are no other offices. I would suggest that the Counselling and Advice Section of the Social Welfare Department should get together with the People's Association and work out a scheme whereby the large staff and voluntary workers at the various community centres, after suitable training, may act as para-counsellors to offer counselling and advice to those who are in need of assistance, as part of a community service which these community centres are supposed to provide.

    Sir, I notice that the Central Narcotics Bureau is stepping up its manpower presumably to tackle more energetically the

Column: 727

serious problem of drug addiction. There is no doubt that an important aspect of their work will involve counselling and advice. There are other departments which are also involved in work of a similar or related nature and will have staff with relevant training and expertise, for example, the psychiatrist attached to the Ministry of Health. If we can pooI all these human and physical resources together and formulate a more comprehensive scheme in counselling and advice and with the support of the public by way of voluntary service, I feel sure that not only would we be able to offer better health to our young people but in the long run to contribute positively towards safeguarding the mental health of our public.

3.00 p.m.

    Mr Chan Chee Seng: Mr Speaker, Sir, at the outset, on behalf of the Ministry. I must thank Hon. Members for their kind words.

    The Ministry of Social Affairs' Counselling and Advice Section at present operates from the headquarters of the Social Welfare Department at Pearl's Hill. At its present location, it has been well accepted. Last year, 6,310 clients used the services of our Counselling and Advice Section, not only for marital disputes but also for other family disputes, pre-marital counselling, help in tracing missing people, disputes with neighbours and tenancy disputes.

    It may be that there is a need, as the Member for Jalan Kayu has pointed out, for these services to be decentralised. In this connection, my Ministry has since 1st December, 1975 established a common intake unit which has the function of receiving all inquiries and requests for social welfare assistance. In December 1 975 alone, the common intake unit dealt with 574 cases which required short-term help and needed reference to other sections.

    With the establishment of this unit, it has become possible to monitor the types of cases that are received, with a view to studying the trends of social welfare needs in

Column: 728

Singapore. Information thus gathered will help to indicate not only whether there is a demand for decentralised counselling services but also the location for which the decentralised services should operate for maximum effect.

    If a need is indicated, the Ministry will consider setting up decentralised services perhaps, as the Hon. Member has suggested, at community centres. This could take the form of area social welfare centres providing advisory information, counselling and referral services to people in the community centres. These centres would also utilise community resources in their operation. Volunteer counsellors and advisers could be engaged from within the community to man them, with expert assistance from a small number of professional social welfare staff.

    With regard to the decentralisation of services and the utilisation of community resources, the Ministry of Social Affairs is launching the community probation service in two constituencies. The idea is to involve volunteer workers at neighbourhood level to counsel and assist probationers. If the scheme is successful, it will be extended to other constituencies.

    Mr Hwang Soo Jin: Sir, I am very pleased with the reply. But may I just draw the attention of the House to the fact that there are altogether only 13 staff in the Counselling and Advice Section. If these 13 officers are the entire staff available to handle 6,000 cases during the course of the year, then I think we must make an award to each and every officer for the very high rate of productivity.

    Sir, on that note, I beg leave to withdraw my amendment.

    Amendment, by leave, withdrawn

    Dr Ong Leong Boon (Kim Seng): Sir, I beg to move,

    That the sum to be allocated for Head R he reduced by $10 in respect of subhead BFA 1109.

    Sir, I would like to take this opportunity to draw the attention of this House, and hopefully public attention and interest, to the

Column: 729

hazards of fire breaking out in high-rise flats and buildings. While it is generally recognised by the Government that fires in such buildings could rapidly develop into disasters way beyond the fire-fighting capacity of the Fire department with inestimable loss to lives and property and certainly a real shokku to public confidence, I am disappointed, Sir, at the lack of positive action by the Government to prevent or to combat fires in high-rise flats and buildings.

    The situation in Singapore today, where some 50% of the population are housed in Housing and Development Board flats, demands very urgent attention. The trend towards building higher and higher upwards, reaching out to embrace the heavenly bodies, must surely awaken planners to the dire consequences of a towering inferno.

    Sir, large blocks of HDB flats are of 16 storeys and above and the present point-block flats are 25 storeys high. Further, private buildings vie for pride of place in the skies way up to 50 storeys. I understand that a 75-storey giant is well on the planning board.

    We have been extremely lucky so far. The God of Fire has benevolently chosen to spare us the agony of its unholy visitation and its almighty fury. However, Sir, we cannot continue to sit back and just pray that our good luck will hold out. We have seen a mini disaster at Robinsons and we have read of awful fires in Seoul city, in Sao Paulo, Latin America, and other parts of the world where tens and sometimes even hundreds of lives were lost, people roasted to death and many more burnt out of all recognition. Let us take immediate steps and make immediate preparations now because tomorrow might be too late.

    Sir, since the 1970s, buildings put up by private enterprises have to be provided with sprinklers and automatic heat detector systems before planning approval is granted. This is, of course, a very sound policy. However, I cannot understand why the Fire department should continue to grant approval to the HDB to erect gigantic structures, some of which house 500 units or

Column: 730

more, without the minimum safeguard against fire. Some HDB flats do not even have a fire exit. It was most regrettable, Sir, that the HDB could publicly claim in the recent past that its flats are fire-safe and that these flats or units are so compartmentalised that fire will not spread from one unit to another. Surely we do not need a test case to make us realise that in case of fire the tenants can only pray for their lives.

    It seems to me, therefore, that the Fire department takes a very partial attitude towards the HDB and this is, wittingly or unwittingly, at the expense of public safety. I would be most happy if the Hon. Minister could enlighten this House regarding the fire-fighting capacity of the Fire department, and to honestly reveal its inadequacies, and what steps are being taken by his Ministry to modernise the fire-fighting capability of the Fire department.

    Further, may I plead with him to start a sustained intensive national campaign of public education through the schools, community centres, commercial enterprises, through the press, over radio and television, on the Dos and Don'ts of fire prevention and fire-fighting. Sir, may I ask the Hon. Minister to enlighten this House on the points I have raised.

    The Minister for Social Affairs (Encik Othman Bin Wok): Mr Speaker, Sir, the Singapore Fire Brigade is aware of the problems involved in fighting fires in high-rise buildings. As early as 1960, the Fire Brigade had insisted that high-rise buildings be provided with built-in fire-fighting facilities and such other preventive measures as are necessary for the protection of lives and property. Also regular fire drills are held in high-rise buildings for members of the Brigade to familiarise themselves with the built-in fire protection facilities. In addition, inspections are also made by fire officers of all high-rise buildings to ensure that the fire protection facilities are in good working order.

    The Fire Brigade will have no special difficulty in fighting a fire, say, on the 50th floor or above the 16th floor of a high-rise

Column: 731

building provided the building, as I said, is equipped with adequate fire protection facilities such as fire lifts, wet rising mains and hose reels. When the Brigade was involved in making recommendations for fire prevention facilities in all buildings to ensure that adequate fire prevention measures were provided, stringent requirements were imposed on high-rise buildings, including the provision of automatic sprinklers and fire detectors, wet and dry rising mains. protected staircases for escape purposes, ventilated lobbies for internal fire fighting, fire lifts for use by firemen in emergencies, hose reels and extinguishers and the use of non-combustible building materials to control the spread of fire. Since 1st August, 1973, this function has been transferred to the Building Control Division of the Public Works Department. However.
